SystemOutput:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports feeling out of sorts, fatigued, and lightheaded for the past five weeks. He attributes this to the change in seasons and increased physical activity due to home renovations. The patient also reports bloating and occasional shortness of breath during exertion. He denies fever, chills, and chest pain but reports a slight cough. The patient has been adhering to his medications and monitoring his blood pressure at home. However, his diet has been off due to the kitchen renovations.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Positive fatigue and lightheadedness. No fever or chills.
• Cardiovascular: No chest pain. Positive bloating.
• Respiratory: Positive shortness of breath during exertion. Positive slight cough.
• Gastrointestinal: No nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital signs: Blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygenation within normal limits.
• Neck: Jugular venous distention to 8 centimeters.
• Heart: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Lungs: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally.
• Lower extremities: 1+ pitting edema.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Fluid in lungs.
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Pumping function reduced at 45%, mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive Heart Failure:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is retaining fluid, as evidenced by physical exam and chest X-ray.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day. Monitor weight daily and report any weight gain or shortness of breath. Order a new echocardiogram.

2. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure is well-managed at this time.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Continue to record blood pressures at home and report any elevations through the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right knee pain.

HPI:

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right knee pain. She reports that she was changing a light bulb on a ladder yesterday when she stumbled and twisted her knee while trying to catch her fall. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it does not seem to help much. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and takes digoxin. She has a past surgical history of a rhinoplasty. She denies any allergies.

EXAM:

Examination of the right knee shows tenderness over the medial portion of the knee, over the medial meniscus area. Pain is elicited with flexion and valgus stress. Normal sensation is present. No pain in the calves.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the left knee obtained on today's visit show no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid present, but everything else appears to be lined up properly.

IMPRESSION:

Acute medial meniscus sprain or strain of the right knee.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended we place her in a knee brace and provide crutches for temporary use. She will follow up in 1 week for reevaluation, and if not improved, we will consider an MRI. I will prescribe Motrin 800 mg, to be taken every 6 hours with food, for a two-week supply.

All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

The patient states he was helping his daughter with heavy equipment and lifted some boxes too quickly, which were too heavy. This happened on Saturday morning, and he heard a pop in his lower back. He had to lie down for about an hour before the pain was relieved, and it has been stiff ever since. He has taken Tylenol, ibuprofen, and used icy heat on the spot, but it did not seem to help. He felt some tingling in his toes on his right foot until Sunday afternoon, which then resolved.

Regarding his diabetes, he admits to having a sweet tooth and not having the best diet recently. He plans to improve his eating habits.

Regarding his hypertension, he monitors his blood pressure readings at home during the week but tends to forget on the weekends. He is taking his medication.

Regarding his osteoarthritis, it gets aggravated occasionally, but it has been manageable.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies weight loss. Denies fever, chills, nausea, or vomiting.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses back pain. Denies chest pain.
• Neurological: Endorses tingling in toes on the right foot, which resolved.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Examination of his back reveals pain to palpation at the lumbar spine. Decreased range of motion with flexion and extension. Negative straight leg raise.

Results:

Back X-ray is unremarkable with good bony alignment.

Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

Acute lumbar strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient reports feeling a 'pop' and immediate pain while lifting heavy boxes. He has tried Tylenol and ibuprofen without significant relief.
• Additional Testing: None at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Initiate meloxicam 15 mg once daily. Continue icing and avoid strenuous activity. Refer to physical therapy.

Diabetes type 2.
• Medical Reasoning: His recent hemoglobin A1c was 8, indicating poor control.
• Additional Testing: Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.
• Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure readings are running on the high side.
• Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

Osteoarthritis.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is managing his knee osteoarthritis well and no further workup is needed at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up in 2 weeks.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam and follow-up of chronic problems.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy. He presents for his annual exam.

Regarding his depression, the patient has been taking Prozac and reports no recent incidents. He has been managing his hypertension with Norvasc, although he admits to occasionally forgetting to take it on weekends.

The patient had a lobectomy a couple of years ago and reports no significant issues with shortness of breath, except during high pollen season and when running in humid conditions.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: Endorses nasal congestion due to pollen.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain, reports occasional pounding in the chest during exertion.
• Respiratory: Shortness of breath with exertion.
• Psychiatric: Endorses depression.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: Pain to palpation of sinuses.
• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Extremities: No lower extremity edema.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: 120/80 mmHg.

RESULTS

Electrocardiogram: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerning findings post-lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Depression.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is doing well on Prozac 20 mg daily.
• Medical Treatment: Continue Prozac 20 mg daily.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Refill prescription for Prozac.

Prior Lobectomy.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is exercising regularly and has good breathing function.
• Medical Treatment: No further follow-up with the surgeon is needed.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure is well-controlled on Norvasc.
• Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram for the murmur.
• Medical Treatment: Continue Norvasc as prescribed.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right index finger pain.

HPI:

Ms. Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right index finger pain after a skiing accident over the weekend. She reports that her finger was bent backward while skiing over moguls.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Miralax

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Constipation
Appendectomy at age 18

EXAM:

Examination of the right index finger shows tenderness over the distal phalanx. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right index finger obtained on today's visit show no fractures and everything lines up well.

IMPRESSION:

Right index finger contusion.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend an aluminum foam splint and a prescription for Motrin 600 mg every 6 hours for a week. If the pain does not improve, the patient is advised to call and return for further evaluation. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a long-standing history of iron deficiency anemia, who presents today for further evaluation. She was recently unable to donate blood due to her anemia. The patient reports fatigue, feverishness, chills, shortness of breath, wheezing, and headaches. She has been anemic since the age of 13 and had a hysterectomy in 1996. Her last colonoscopy was approximately 5-6 years ago with no significant findings. She denies any history of heavy periods, pacemaker or defibrillator use, sleep apnea, or oxygen use at night. She drinks alcohol only once or twice a year.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Endorses fatigue, feverishness, and chills.
• Respiratory: Endorses shortness of breath and wheezing.
• Neurological: Endorses headaches.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

• Ferrous sulfate 25 mg tablets, twice daily.
• Over-the-counter vitamin B12.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: Normal physical exam without any significant findings.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Ms. Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a long-standing history of iron deficiency anemia, who presents today for further evaluation.

Iron deficiency anemia.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has been dealing with anemia since the age of 13, and her recent blood work revealed low hemoglobin, stable hematocrit, normal iron labs, and low ferritin. She is currently taking ferrous sulfate and vitamin B12.
• Additional Testing: We will recheck her CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate levels in 8-12 weeks after continuing her iron supplementation with orange juice for better absorption.
• Specialist Referrals: We will refer her to a hematologist for further evaluation and possible intravenous iron therapy or other treatments to help her body store iron better.
• Diagnostic Procedures: We will schedule an upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If these tests are inconclusive, we will consider a capsule endoscopy.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for consultation regarding a newly diagnosed pituitary lesion. The patient was referred by Dr. Henry Howard for possible surgical intervention. Mr. Ward has been experiencing worsening headaches over the past few months, with no prior history of headaches. His past clinical history is unremarkable. Workup for headaches was initiated with brain MRI and serology, where the pituitary lesion was incidentally discovered. The patient's pituitary hormone profile demonstrates a low TSH, with all other results being normal. MRI of the brain with contrast reveals a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm.

The patient reports headaches located behind his eyes, described as a dull nagging ache, with a gradual onset and worsening over time. The headaches are worse in the morning and last a few hours at a time. The patient denies any other symptoms, such as fever, rashes, neck stiffness, numbness, weakness, or passing out. However, he has recently noticed bumping into door frames.

PAST HISTORY

Adopted, family medical history unknown.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Computer programmer, married for 25 years, recently bought a small house. Non-smoker, non-drinker, and no recreational drug use.

EXAMINATION

The patient is alert, oriented to time, place, and person. Affect is appropriate and speech is fluent. Cranial nerve examination is grossly intact. No focal motor or sensory deficit in the upper or lower extremities. Visual acuity and eye movements are normal. Pupils are equal and reactive. Visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia. Color vision is normal.

ASSESSMENT

Pituitary adenoma with optic chiasmal compression.

PLAN

1. Refer the patient to an eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test to map peripheral vision prior to surgery.
2. Schedule surgery for transsphenoidal approach to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa.
3. Counsel the patient on the risks associated with surgery and anesthesia.
4. Monitor the patient's vision post-surgery to assess improvement.
5. Encourage the patient to call if any questions arise.

End of note.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill is a 53-year-old female with a past medical history of uterine fibroids, anemia, and gallbladder removal. She presents as a new patient with a referral from the ER for esophagitis. The patient experienced chest pain for four days in early October 2020, which resolved on its own. She has not had any chest pain since then. The pain was located in the center of her chest, behind her breastbone, and was sharp in nature. The patient also experienced difficulty swallowing during the episode, which has since resolved. The pain was worse with eating. She denies any abdominal pain and reports normal bowel movements. The patient has been trying to lose weight and has no known family history of GI problems.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Abdomen
• Examination of Abdomen: Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. No pain or tenderness in the lower abdomen.

RESULTS

ER visit: EKG and blood tests were normal.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

The patient is a 53-year-old female who presents with a history of chest pain and difficulty swallowing, which resolved on its own. The ER ruled out cardiac issues, and possible etiologies include GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal etiologies, and anxiety. The patient reported a stressful job transition during the time of her symptoms, which may have contributed to her condition.

Given the patient's current asymptomatic status, the plan is to hold off on an EGD and monitor for any additional symptoms. The patient will call the office if she experiences any episodes of pain or other concerning symptoms. If needed, an EGD will be scheduled. The patient will follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended monitoring plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Possible kidney anomalies in a patient with Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome, presenting today for evaluation of possible kidney anomalies. She is a twin, born at 34 weeks and 3 days gestation, with a birth weight of 4 pounds, 8 ounces. The patient has a history of feeding difficulties, reflux, and developmental delays. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, and physical therapy. She will also be starting speech therapy soon. The patient has seen multiple specialists, including a geneticist, who mentioned the possibility of kidney anomalies in patients with Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Patient is growing and developing, albeit with some delays.
• Gastrointestinal: History of reflux and feeding difficulties.
• Genitourinary: 8-10 wet diapers per day, no known issues with urinary tract.
• Neurological: Developmental delays, currently in multiple therapies.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined.
• Eyes: Small appearing.
• Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities in her arms.
• Genitourinary: Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome, presenting today for evaluation of possible kidney anomalies.

• Medical Reasoning: Congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract have been reported in the literature for patients with Smith-Magenis Syndrome. The patient has no known issues with her urinary tract and has a normal number of wet diapers per day.
• Additional Testing: We will obtain a kidney ultrasound today to screen for any abnormalities.
• Follow-up: If there are abnormalities on the kidney ultrasound, we will determine next steps and future follow-up. The family lives in Dallas, Georgia, so her follow-up should be at the town center location. If the ultrasound is normal, the patient will not need to see me again.

Patient Agreements: The patient's guardian understands and agrees with the recommended medical evaluation plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain and swelling.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right wrist pain and swelling. The onset of her pain began when she slipped on the stairs while doing laundry and tried to catch herself with her right arm. The patient reports severe pain, rated as a 9 out of 10. She has been icing her wrist, using an ace wrap, and taking ibuprofen, which provided minimal relief. The injury occurred yesterday morning. The patient denies any previous injuries to her right arm.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Positive right wrist pain and swelling.
Neurological: Mild tingling in fingers, no numbness.

VITALS

BP: 140/70
HR: 80 bpm
RR: 20
Temp: 97.2°F
SPO2: Not mentioned.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head/Neck: No adenopathy, thyromegaly, or carotid bruit.
CV: No murmur, rub, or gallop.
Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Extremities: No lower leg edema, palpable pulses.
Right Wrist: Obvious swelling, ecchymosis, tenderness on palpation, bony crepitus, pain on flexion, extension, abduction, and adduction. Able to make a fist but not tightly.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right wrist reveals a positive Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT

Colles' fracture of the right wrist.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to her current symptoms. I have explained to her that her symptoms are consistent with a Colles' fracture. I have recommended conservative treatment initially with a brace for her right wrist. The patient will be scheduled for surgery as soon as possible. Post-surgery, the patient will be placed in a brace for six weeks and will attend physical therapy three times per week. The patient will be prescribed 50 mg of Ultram every six hours for pain management.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will return for a follow-up appointment in one month to assess her progress and discuss her upcoming vacation plans. If her pain does not improve or worsens, she will contact the office.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, on 20 mg Lisinopril.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 150/70 mmHg
Heart rate: Not provided
Respiration: Not provided
No fever.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Assessment of Respiratory Effort: Lungs clear bilaterally, no wheezes or crackles.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Musculoskeletal
- Right knee: Pain with flexion and extension. Pain to palpation of the medial aspect. Edema around the knee and effusion present. No pain on the lateral aspect.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee were obtained and reviewed. No fractures or bony abnormalities were found.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee MCL strain.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient slipped and fell, causing pain and swelling in the right knee.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for pain and swelling. Provide a knee brace for support and recommend icing the knee for 20 minutes, 3-4 times daily. Advise the patient to elevate and rest the leg.
- Follow-up: Reevaluate in a few weeks.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has a history of hypertension and is currently on 20 mg Lisinopril. Blood pressure was elevated at 150/70 mmHg during the visit.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discuss the importance of a low-sodium diet and lifestyle modifications to manage hypertension.
- Medical Treatment: Continue 20 mg Lisinopril. Refer the patient to a nutritionist for dietary guidance.
- Follow-up: Monitor blood pressure and adjust treatment as needed.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in a few weeks.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left shoulder pain. The onset of his pain began 3 weeks ago, without any improvement. He denies any specific injury; however, he has been renovating his basement and putting in a new ceiling. He does not recall hitting or falling onto the left shoulder. The patient states he is very active and has experienced left shoulder pain before that usually resolves with Tylenol.

The patient reports significant pain with reaching, lifting, and overhead activities. The pain is constant. He states the pain is primarily located in the left shoulder and denies it radiates down into the left arm. The patient also reports difficulty sleeping secondary to the pain. He denies any numbness or tingling in his left arm or fingers. He has been taking Tylenol for pain, which provides partial relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left shoulder pain. Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling.

VITALS

All vital signs are within the normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Examination of the left shoulder: Limited active and passive ROM. Tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or AC joints. Good hand grip. Neurovascularly intact distally. Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds. Sensation is intact to light touch distally.

RESULTS

X-rays of the left shoulder were obtained and reviewed today. These are normal and reveal no fracture or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, likely rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with him regarding his current symptoms. I have explained that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture. I have recommended that we obtain an MRI of the left shoulder to evaluate for possible rotator cuff tendinopathy. The patient was provided with a referral to formal physical therapy. He will engage in a 6-to-8-week course in order to strengthen his left shoulder. I have also advised him to take Tylenol as needed for pain. If his symptoms do not improve, we may consider a steroid injection to the left shoulder.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me once the MRI results are available for review and further discussion.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain and instability.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left knee pain and instability. The patient reports that her left knee occasionally gives out while walking, causing her to almost fall. She states that the pain is internal and involves the whole kneecap area. The pain comes and goes quickly, and she has not experienced any popping sensations or previous injuries to the knee. The patient denies taking any medications for pain, as it does not last long. She is concerned about her upcoming trip, which will involve a lot of walking and line dancing, and is considering not participating in the dancing due to her knee issues.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left knee pain and instability. Denies right knee pain.

Cardiovascular: Reports taking blood pressure medication regularly.

Endocrine: Reports taking metformin for diabetes management.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: Temperature 98.2, Pulse 72, Respirations 16, Blood Pressure 122/70.

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base.

Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.

MSK: Examination of the left knee: No ecchymosis, edema, or effusion. No pain to palpation of the left medial knee. No decreased range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee x-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

1. Left knee pain and instability, likely due to arthritis.
2. Hypertension.
3. Diabetes mellitus.

PLAN

1. For the left knee pain and instability, prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider initiating physical therapy to strengthen the muscles around the knee.
2. Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension management and order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.
3. Order a hemoglobin A1C test and lipid panel to assess diabetes management and potential adjustments to metformin dosage.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Cough and sore throat.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer, currently undergoing neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. Biopsy of a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule was positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports good support from family members and nursing staff.

MEDICATIONS

Cisplatin and etoposide chemotherapy.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fatigue.
Respiratory: Reports minimal cough and sore throat, no shortness of breath.
Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea or vomiting, reports decreased appetite.

VITALS

Oxygen saturation: Within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head and Neck
- Examination: No cervical lymphadenopathy or supraclavicular adenopathy.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Crackles bilaterally.

Skin
- Examination: Erythema on the anterior side of the chest on the left side, likely related to radiation.

Lower Extremities
- Examination: No edema.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Non-small cell lung cancer.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient is currently undergoing chemotherapy with cisplatin and etoposide, and radiation therapy.
- Medical Treatment: Continue current chemotherapy regimen and radiation dose of 45 Gy. Repeat imaging after completion of therapy to assess tumor response and potential for surgical resection.

2. Radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's cough and crackles on lung exam are likely due to radiation-induced inflammation.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation and improve symptoms.

3. Painful swallowing.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's sore throat and difficulty swallowing may be due to radiation-induced inflammation in the esophagus.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow four times a day to alleviate pain and facilitate eating and drinking.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Low immunoglobulin A level.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient was referred by their primary care physician due to a low immunoglobulin A level found during a recent physical exam. Patient reports frequent colds during the winter that tend to linger but is unsure if this is more than usual.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Type 2 diabetes, recently started on metformin.

FAMILY HISTORY

No known family history of immune deficiencies.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient works at a family-owned donut shop.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: No fever.
Respiratory: No shortness of breath, wheezing, or chest pain.
Gastrointestinal: No abdominal pain or diarrhea.

VITALS

Within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Respiratory: Lungs clear, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Neck: No lymphadenopathy.
Abdominal: Soft, non-tender, no organomegaly.

LABORATORY

Low immunoglobulin A level.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Low immunoglobulin A level.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's lab work is consistent with an IgA deficiency, a common immunodeficiency. Most people with this deficiency live normal lives without knowing they have it, but some may experience frequent respiratory, sinus, or abdominal infections. In this case, the patient does not seem to have a significant history of infections.
- Additional Testing: Order blood work to check for other antibodies to rule out other immunodeficiencies.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the nature of IgA deficiency with the patient and advised them to watch for infections that do not resolve or are difficult to control, as well as any changes in their abdominal tract. Informed the patient to notify healthcare providers of their IgA deficiency if they ever need blood products.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended assessment and plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right elbow pain. The patient has been experiencing right elbow pain for approximately 4 days. He reports that the pain is localized to the inside of his elbow and can radiate down into his forearm. He denies any trauma or previous injury to the right elbow. The patient has been engaging in pottery activities recently, which he believes may have contributed to the pain. He has tried ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal success.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient has been engaging in pottery activities during the pandemic.

MEDICATIONS

The patient reports that he has been taking ibuprofen for pain relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right elbow pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: 
Examination of the right elbow: Pain to palpation along the medial aspect. No pain with supination. Pain with pronation. Pain with resistance against flexion of the left wrist.

RESULTS

X-ray images of the right elbow were obtained and reviewed in the office today. These reveal no evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

Right medial epicondylitis.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, we discussed the diagnosis of medial epicondylitis. The patient is advised to rest the affected elbow, wear a sling while awake, apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes three times a day, and take ibuprofen 600 mg q.6 h. with food for a full week. The patient is also advised to refrain from pottery activities for the next couple of weeks. A follow-up appointment is scheduled for one week to evaluate the patient's progress.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Emergency department follow up after falling and chest pain.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Bumex 2 mg once daily, Cozaar 100 mg daily, and Norvasc 5 mg once daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies sleep disturbance.
Cardiovascular: Reports chest pain.
Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath.
Genitourinary: Denies urinary incontinence.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 128/72 mmHg
Temperature: 98.7 degrees F
Heart Rate: 72 bpm
Oxygen Saturation: 96%

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: No jugular venous distention.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Stable 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Clear bilaterally.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Trace lower extremity edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram reveals a preserved ejection fraction of 55%, abnormal diastolic filling, and mild-to-moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure.
- Medical Reasoning: This appears to have been caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to continue making dietary modifications, including limiting sodium intake. Referral placed for consult with a nutritionist for education and recommendations regarding diet.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with Bumex 2 mg once daily.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: This has been poorly controlled due to inconsistent compliance with medication and dietary indiscretion.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed dietary modifications as noted above.
- Medical Treatment: Continue on Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg once daily. Renal artery ultrasound ordered to rule out any issues such as renal artery stenosis.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 3 months.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right-sided abdominal pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a patient who presents with sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain radiates to his lower abdomen and groin. The pain is intermittent and comes in severe episodes. He reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine. He has taken Tylenol for the pain with minimal relief. The patient has a history of kidney stones and a family history of kidney stones (father). His primary care physician ordered a CT scan, which revealed a kidney stone, and referred him to a urologist.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Gastrointestinal: Reports nausea but no vomiting.
Genitourinary: Reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine.

VITALS

Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs.
CVA: Positive tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS

The CT scan of the abdomen revealed a 0.5 cm stone located in the proximal right ureter. There is no evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Acute nephrolithiasis (kidney stone).

PLAN

1. Encourage increased fluid intake to facilitate urination and stone passage.
2. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours as needed for pain. Patient may continue to take Tylenol as needed.
3. Provide a strainer for the patient to strain urine and collect the stone when it passes.
4. Order a basic metabolic panel (BMP), urinalysis, and urine culture.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 1 to 2 weeks to assess progress. If symptoms persist, discuss further treatment options such as lithotripsy or ureteroscopy.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is advised to contact the healthcare provider if symptoms worsen or new symptoms develop.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Non-healing right foot ulcer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a patient with a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy who presents today for evaluation of a non-healing right foot ulcer. He reports having the ulcer for approximately 6 weeks, which he first noticed after wearing tight shoes and going on a hike. The patient describes the ulcer as having a foul smell, yellow drainage, and blackened edges. He has been on antibiotics for 6 days and has experienced some improvement but still has redness, swelling, and pain in his calf. He also reports recent difficulty catching his breath and coughing. His blood sugars have been trending higher in the past few weeks, with some readings in the 300-400 range.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy. His last hemoglobin A1c was 6.7.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient enjoys hiking and recently went on a hike at a new trail.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking antibiotics for the foot ulcer.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Patient reports fever and chills.
Cardiovascular: No chest pain.
Respiratory: Patient reports coughing and difficulty catching breath.
Skin: Patient reports non-healing right foot ulcer.
Neurological: No headaches or numbness/tingling in feet.

VITALS

Slight fever.
Blood pressure: Not provided
Heart rate: Not provided

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Not provided
RESPIRATORY: Not provided
NECK: Not provided
MSK: Examination of the right foot reveals a 2 x 2 cm necrotic wound on the heel with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, and erythemia. No bony exposure. Vascular exam shows bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses, but no palpable dorsalis pedis or posterior tibial pulses (present via Doppler). No pain on palpation of the affected area.

ASSESSMENT

1. Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer, right foot
2. Diabetes with recent blood sugar instability
3. Possible cellulitis

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination findings today, I have discussed with the patient his current symptoms and the following plan:

1. Order a test to check blood supply for the wound.
2. Perform debridement of the wound in the office today.
3. Obtain a culture of the wound and consider adjusting antibiotic therapy based on culture results.
4. Continue current antibiotic therapy and monitor the redness and swelling in the calf.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 7 days.
6. Recommend the patient to follow up with his endocrinologist for diabetes management and maintain a hemoglobin A1c below 7.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee with erythema and edema.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports spending time outdoors and recently went hunting. He noticed a tick bite on his right knee over a week ago, which has been burning and causing discomfort. He denies fever or chills but reports feeling generally unwell and experiencing headaches since the tick bite.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, Diabetes

MEDICATIONS

Lisinopril 20 mg daily, Metformin 1000 mg twice daily

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, reports feeling generally unwell.
Musculoskeletal: Denies joint pain other than typical arthritic pain.
Neurological: Reports headaches since tick bite.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 122/70 mmHg
Heart rate: 67 bpm
Respiration: Not reported
Temperature: 98.4°F

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs.
Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Musculoskeletal: Full range of motion in right knee. Pain to palpation of right anterior knee.
Skin: Bull's-eye rash over right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Suspected Lyme disease due to tick bite and bull's-eye rash.
   - Medical Treatment: Start Doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 3 weeks.
   - Diagnostic Testing: Order Lyme titer and Western blot to confirm diagnosis.

2. Hypertension
   - Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily.
   - Diagnostic Testing: Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.

3. Diabetes
   - Continue Metformin 1000 mg twice daily.
   - Diagnostic Testing: Order Hemoglobin A1c to assess long-term blood sugar control.
   - Patient Education: Encourage patient to continue monitoring blood sugar levels and maintain a healthy diet.

4. Kidney function
   - Diagnostic Testing: Order basic metabolic panel to assess kidney function.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.
